articles.headline: Iraqi Elections Face Crucial Test in Violent Mosul
articles.snippet: The elections will test whether a political system that represents ethnic and sectarian splits will foster stability.
articles.abstract: The elections will test whether a political system that represents ethnic and sectarian splits will foster stability.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSUL, Iraq  The thud of the car bomb was familiar, if in this case close, rattling the windows and puffing out the drapes.

articles.headline: Global Worries Over U.S. Stimulus Spending
articles.snippet: The long-term fallout from increased borrowing by the U.S. government seems to getting more attention in Davos than in Washington.
articles.abstract: The long-term fallout from increased borrowing by the U.S. government seems to getting more attention in Davos than in Washington.
articles.lead_paragraph: DAVOS, Switzerland  Even as Congress looks for ways to expand President Obama’s $819 billion stimulus package, the rest of the world is wondering how Washington will pay for it all.

articles.headline: Obama Calls Wall Street Bonuses ‘Shameful’
articles.snippet: The president criticized bankers for giving themselves $18.4 billion in bonuses as the government was rescuing firms.
articles.abstract: The president criticized bankers for giving themselves $18.4 billion in bonuses as the government was rescuing firms.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Obama branded Wall Street bankers “shameful” on Thursday for giving themselves nearly $20 billion in bonuses as the economy was deteriorating and the government was spending billions to bail out some of the nation’s most prominent financial institutions.
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Stephen Labaton

articles.headline: A Global Credit Squeeze Is Felt Unevenly
articles.snippet: The recession in the U.S. has revealed a downside to globalization, and poorer countries fear their access to credit will be stymied.
articles.abstract: The recession in the U.S. has revealed a downside to globalization, and poorer countries fear their access to credit will be stymied.

articles.headline: Senators Bid to Regulate Hedge Funds
articles.snippet: Legislation from Senator Carl Levin and Senator Charles E. Grassley would give the S.E.C. specific authority to oversee hedge funds.
articles.abstract: Legislation from Senator Carl Levin and Senator Charles E. Grassley would give the S.E.C. specific authority to oversee hedge funds.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Two senior senators introduced legislation on Thursday to impose government oversight of hedge funds.

articles.headline: Billable Hours Giving Ground at Law Firms
articles.snippet: With clients watching costs, law firms are rethinking the billable hour, with some firms adopting flat fees instead.
articles.abstract: With clients watching costs, law firms are rethinking the billable hour, with some firms adopting flat fees instead.
articles.lead_paragraph: Lawyers are having trouble defending the most basic yardstick of the legal business  the billable hour.

articles.headline: Upbeat but Sympathetic: A Fine Line for Super Bowl Ads
articles.snippet: Advertisers for the Super Bowl are walking a tightrope this year, trying to entertain and sell products, while not appearing insensitive to the economic environment.
articles.abstract: Advertisers for the Super Bowl are walking a tightrope this year, trying to entertain and sell products, while not appearing insensitive to the economic environment.
articles.lead_paragraph: For television viewers, the Super Bowl offers an annual midwinter spectacle. On Sunday, in addition to a football game and a halftime show, they can watch Madison Avenue try to walk a tightrope.

articles.headline: Few Ways to Recover Bonuses to Bankers
articles.snippet: Despite calls for so-called clawbacks on financial bonuses, the legal options to force their return are few.
articles.abstract: Despite calls for so-called clawbacks on financial bonuses, the legal options to force their return are few.
articles.byline: By Eric Dash and Vikas Bajaj

articles.headline: Jailed C.I.A. Mole Kept Spying for Russia, via Son, U.S. Says
articles.snippet: Harold Nicholson is said to have sought more money from his handlers, using his son as a go-between.
articles.abstract: Harold Nicholson is said to have sought more money from his handlers, using his son as a go-between.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Since 1997, Harold Nicholson has been locked in a federal prison in Oregon, the highest-ranking officer of the Central Intelligence Agency ever convicted of espionage.

articles.headline: Blagojevich Makes a Day of It on Way Out
articles.snippet: On his final day as governor of Illinois, Rod R. Blagojevich was, by turns, furious, morose and full of gallows humor.
articles.abstract: On his final day as governor of Illinois, Rod R. Blagojevich was, by turns, furious, morose and full of gallows humor.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — As the nine-seat airplane raced through the skies on Thursday somewhere between Springfield and here, an onboard telephone began to ring.

articles.headline: Steep Slide in Economy as Unsold Goods Pile Up
articles.snippet: The gross domestic product saw its biggest contraction in 26 years in the quarter, adding to the urgency of a stimulus package to rein in the recession.
articles.abstract: The gross domestic product saw its biggest contraction in 26 years in the quarter, adding to the urgency of a stimulus package to rein in the recession.
articles.lead_paragraph: The economy shrank at an accelerating pace late last year, the government reported on Friday, adding to the urgency of a stimulus package capable of bringing the country back from a recession that appears to be deepening.
